About Me

Hi! I am a fresh graduate of the University of Michigan and one of the co-founders of HardBoiled Studios, a student-led game studio that is currently developing their debut game, Yolked.

In my senior year, I conducted research on machine learning prediction biases with Serena Xiong, a fellow undergraduate researcher, and Dr. Sindhu Kutty, a professor of Machine Learning. Our research was presented at the virtual Grace Hopper Conference and won third place in the ACM Student Research Competition.

On the side, I also love to develop games. After taking a video game development course in university, two students and I took our final project, Yolked, and decided to start HardBoiled Studios and bring it all the way to the finish line. We have partnered with a publisher, Hitcents, to turn Yolked into a published intellectual property by the end of 2021.

Portfolio

Programming Projects

Yolked

March 2020-Present

Yolked is a action-adventure video game in the making by HardBoiled Studios. Started out as a final project for a Video Game Development course, two friends and I decided to bring it to the finish line after winning first place in the class showcase. We recently signed a contract with an indie-game publisher with the view of publishing the game on Steam and other large gaming platforms by the end of 2021.

Check Project




Back 2 Back

March 2020

Back 2 Back is a web-game created in 48 hours by HardBoiled Studios and won first place at the WolverineSoft 2020 Shammy Game Jam. In Back 2 Back, follow two buddies as they defend themselves against spikes and lasers, but there's a twist–-you must control both players at the same time as they stand back-to-back.

Check Project




Color Array

February 2020

Color Array is a rapid prototype of a puzzle-platformer web-game created in two weeks. With a focus on game design and guidance, the game slowly teaches players the color-jumping mechanic by a gradual increase in level difficulty. The game has 7 levels of increasing difficulty. Reach the star on all levels to complete the game!

Check Project




Legend of Zelda (Unity Remastered)

January 2020 - February 2020

Made by two people in three weeks, this web-game is a remastered version of the first dungeon in the Legend of Zelda (NES). The dungeon features all the original enemies and mechanics. In addition, there is a new level with a unique mechanic that can be accessed by pressing '4'.

Check Project




Research Projects

Fairness in COMPAS

December 2019 - October 2020

The risk of recidivism is considered when sentencing criminal defendants. While Machine Learning algorithms have been deployed to calculate this risk, the racial fairness of these algorithms is unclear. Replicating prior work, we evaluate different definitions of fairness in this research project. We additionally demonstrate how racially-aware predictors could be used to achieve fairness with minimal effects on accuracy.

Check Project




Reaction Miniaturization in Eco-friendly Solvents

May 2018

Advanced chemical intermediates used in pharmaceutical research are often produced for the first time via multistep synthetic routes that are neither optimal nor green. We highlight technologies, with case studies, for running synthetic reactions in parallel from the milligram to microgram scale in glass vials and plastic wellplates.

Check Project

Devblog

Project Randomizer is a research project that explores procedural generation in video games.

It has been estimated that the video game industry will be a $159.3 billion dollar industry in 2020, with estimations that it will exceed $200 billion by 2023 (Newzoo 2020) and $300 billion by 2025 (Forbes 2020). In addition, the world currently has 2.7 billion gamers, which is more than a third of the world’s population (Newzoo 2020). As the industry grows exponentially and is changing rapidly, it is important that we continue finding ways to improve and polish video games.

Video game developers may often feel stuck when creating levels during development as there may be limited time, cost and memory. Procedural generation is a way for data in video games, such as levels, characters and the environment, to be created algorithmically. This method could have multiple advantages, including creating dynamic content, saving memory usage, saving development time and saving money (Packt 2016). This project will attempt to explore that concept by creating an algorithm that will procedurally generate levels for a novel puzzle game, allowing more dynamic content to be created for people to enjoy while saving time, cost and memory usage.
